chunks.text: OK.  Today's topic is differential diagnosis.  And so I'm just quoting Wikipedia here.  Diagnosis is the identification of the nature and cause  of a certain phenomenon.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: And differential diagnosis is the distinguishing  of a particular disease or condition  from others that present similar clinical features.  So doctors typically talk about differential diagnosis  when they're faced with a patient

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: and they make a list of what are the things that  might be wrong with this patient.  And then they go through the process  of trying to figure out which one it actually is.  So that's what we're going to focus on today.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: Now, just to scare you, here's a lovely model  of human circulatory physiology.  So this is from Guyton's textbook of cardiology.  And I'm not going to hold you responsible for all  of the details of this model.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: But it's interesting because this is, at least as of maybe  20 years ago, the state of the art of how people understood  what happens in the circulatory system.  And it has various control inputs  that determine things like how your hormone levels change

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: various aspects of the cardiovascular system  and how the interactions between different components  of the cardiovascular system affect each other.  And so in principle, if I could tune this model to me,  then I could make all kinds of pretty good predictions

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: that say, if I increase my systemic vascular resistance,  then here's what's going to happen as the rest of the system  adjusts.  And if I get a blockage in a coronary artery,  then here's what's going to happen to my cardiac output

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: and various other things.  So this would be terrific.  And if we had this kind of model for not just  the cardiovascular system but the entire body,  then we'd say, OK, we've solved medicine.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: Well, we don't have this kind of model for most systems.  And also, there's this minor problem  that if I give you this model and say,  how does this relate to a particular patient,  how would you figure that out?

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: This has hundreds of differential equations  that are being represented by this diagram.  And they have many hundreds of parameters.  And so we were joking when we started  working with this model that you'd really

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: have to kill the patient in order  to do enough measurements to be able to tune this model  to their particular physiology.  And of course, that's probably not a good practical approach.  We're getting a little better by developing

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: more non-invasive ways of measuring these things.  But that's moving along very slowly.  And I don't expect that I or maybe even any of you  will live long enough that this approach  to doing medical reasoning and medical diagnosis

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: is actually going to happen.  So what we're going to look at today  is what simpler models are there for diagnostic reasoning?  And I'm going to take the liberty of inflicting  a bit of history on you, because I

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: think it's interesting where a lot of these ideas came from.  So the first idea was to build flow charts.  Oh, and by the way, signs and symptoms,  I've forgotten if we've talked about that in the class.  So a sign is something that a doctor sees.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: And a symptom is something that the patient experiences.  So a sign is objective.  It's something that can be told outside your body.  A symptom is something that you feel.  So if you're feeling dizzy, then that's

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: a symptom, because it's not obvious to somebody outside you  that you're dizzy or that you have a pain or such things.  Normally, we talk about manifestations or findings,  which is sort of a super category of all the things  that are determinable about a patient.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: So we'll talk about flow charts, models  based on associations between diseases  and these manifestations.  Then there are some issues about whether you're  trying to diagnose a single disease

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: or a multiplicity of diseases, which makes the models much  more complicated, whether you're trying  to do probabilistic diagnosis or definitive or categorical.  And then we'll talk about some utility theoretic methods.  And I'll just mention some rule-based and pattern

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: matching kinds of approaches.  So this is kind of cute.  This is from 1973.  And if you were a woman and walked into the MIT Health  Center and complained of potentially a urinary tract

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: infection, they would take out this sheet  of paper, which was nicely color-coded,  and they would check a bunch of boxes.  And if you hit a red box, that represented a conclusion.  And otherwise, it gave you suggestions

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: about what further tests to do.  And this was essentially a triage instrument.  It said, does this woman have a problem that  requires immediate attention?  So we should either call an ambulance

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: and take them to a hospital, or is it something  where we can just tell them to come back the next day  and see a doctor?  Or is it, in fact, some self-limited thing  where we say, take two aspirin, and it'll go away?

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: So that was the attempt here.  Now, interestingly, if you look at the history  of this project between the Beth Israel Hospital and Lincoln  Laboratories, it started off as a computer aid.  So they were building a computer system

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: that was supposed to do this.  But you can imagine, in the late 1960s, early 1970s,  computers were pretty clunky.  PCs hadn't been invented yet, so this  was like mainframe kinds of operations.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: It was very hard to use.  And so they said, well, this is a small enough program  that we can reduce it to about 20 sheets like this, which  they proceeded to print up.  And I was amused, because around 1980,

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: I was working in my office one night,  and I got this splitting headache.  And I went over to MIT Medical, and sure enough,  the nurse pulled out one of these sheets for headaches  and went through it with me and decided that a couple of Tylenol

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: should fix me.  But it was interesting.  So this was really in use for a while.  Now, the difficulty with approaches  like this, of which there have been many, many, many

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: in the medical world, is that they're very fragile.  They're very specific.  They don't take account of unusual cases.  And there's a lot of effort in coming to consensus  to build these things.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: And then they're not necessarily useful for a long time.  So MIT actually stopped using them shortly  after my headache experience.  But if you go over to a hospital and you  look on the bookshelf of a junior doctor,

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: you will still find manuals that look kind of like this,  that say, how do we deal with tropical diseases?  So you ask a bunch of questions, and then  depending on the branching logic of the flowchart,  it'll tell you whether this is serious or not.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: And the reason is because if you do your medical training  in Boston, you're not going to see very many tropical diseases.  And so you don't have a base of experience  on the basis of which you can learn and become  an expert at doing it.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: So they use this as a kind of cheat sheet.  I mentioned that the association between diseases and symptoms  is another important way of doing diagnosis.  And I swear to you, there was a paper in the 1960s,  I think, that actually proposed this.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: So if any of you have hung around ancient libraries,  libraries used to have card catalogs  that were physical pieces of paper, of cardboard.  And one of the things they did with these  was each card would be a book.

chunks.title: part.000.mp3
chunks.text: And then around the edges were a bunch of photographs.
